channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Mart√≠nez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: August jobs report shows cracks in U.S. labor market
item.description: U.S. employers added just 22,000 jobs in August, according to a report from the Labor Department, while revised figures showed a net loss of jobs in June for the first time since 2020.

item.title: 'New York Times' investigates Navy SEAL mission in North Korea
item.description: How did a top secret U.S. military mission into North Korea fall apart? NPR's A Martinez speaks with Dave Philipps, a national correspondent for the New York Times, about what went wrong in the 2019 operation.

item.title: White House economist Stephen Miran likely to be confirmed to Fed board of governors
item.description: White House economist Stephen Miran appears likely to win confirmation for a job on the Federal Reserve's board of governors, after a contentious hearing Thursday.

item.title: Democrat who called RFK Jr. a 'charlatan' says U.S. is vulnerable to next pandemic
item.description: Sen. Maria Cantwell, a Democrat from Washington, says Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is "not following the science," like he said he would during his confirmation hearings earlier this year.

item.title: Health Secretary RFK Jr. grilled on vaccines and more during Senate hearing
item.description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. was questioned by senators from both parties on Thursday about vaccine access and more. NPR analyzes the health secretary's nearly three-hour appearance.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: RFK Jr. grilled on vaccines during Senate hearing, European coalition announces plan for security guarantees in Ukraine once war ends, D.C.'s attorney general sues to end National Guard deployment.

item.title: Susan Stamberg, 'founding mother' of NPR, retires
item.description: After more than 50 years behind the mic at NPR, Susan Stamberg is retiring.

item.title: Millions of student loan borrowers are at risk of defaulting, data shows
item.description: New data reveals a growing problem; millions of federal student loan borrowers are at serious risk of default.

item.title: Former Israeli negotiator on Israel's settlement plan in the West Bank
item.description: NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with former Israeli peace negotiator Daniel Levy about Israel's latest settlement plan in the occupied West Bank.

item.title: Why the end of the de minimus tariff exemption is causing shipping chaos worldwide
item.description: Planet Money looks at what the de minimis tariff exemption is, who wins and loses with the end of this policy and why ending it has resulting in shipping chaos worldwide.
